review:
Between this and Darkest Hour it's hard to say which is the best of the HOI games - as they both diverge in different directions. Ideally we could get a hybrid game one day, which combines all their strong suits: Darkest Hour's map, casualty system, tech tree with AOD's economic and logistic system. Now that would be the ultimate HOI2 experience! 

Anyway, if you aren't familiar with Hearts of Iron 2 I would probably recommend Darkest Hour first before this one, as it was easier to get into. But this is an excellent game and I highly recommend it if you have an interest in WW2 and the early Cold War!

author: {'steamid': '76561198094604569', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 59554, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 1, 'playtime_at_review': 56774, 'last_played': 1710593503}
review:
Очень качественная модификация оригинальной HoI2, которая стала сложнее и намного глубже за счет добавления новых фишек, отсутствующих в ванили. 

По техническим моментам - игра хорошо адаптирована под современное железо, торговые соглашения правда сжирают много ресурсов ПК, видимо связано с их обработкой, ведь теперь торговые маршруты не мнимые. Хорошо переработана логистика (пока, СССР), новые фотографии дивизий, провинций, более сложные сражения из-за изменения баланса (теперь советская доктрина на уровне с французской, авианосцы теперь менее смертоносные), автоматизированный шпионаж, который теперь нужный. Окно производства переработано на совесть! В целом игра на возможности более гибкая. Добавлены новые страны, изменено поведение ИИ. Починили бригады (до этого ИИ строил одних инженеров). Теперь у СССР есть шанс устоять против Германии. Я крайне рекомендую ветеранам серии. Все это актуально для последнего патча 1.13

Игра мультиязычная - русский язык уже вшит в игру. Если он режет глаз, тут моя заплатка: https://forum.paradoxplaza.com/forum/threads/rus-language.1169964/page-2 Проблема русского языка - это оригинальный перевод 1С, а у нас куча новых окон, которые не переведены или переведены очень коряво. По этому просто комплексная правка текста и исправление ошибок, никакой отсебятины.

author: {'steamid': '76561199050276704', 'num_games_owned': 152, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 10918, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 266, 'last_played': 1703626997}
review:
— Так… ну я тебе щас лекцию прочитаю.

— Хорошо.

— Сиди вон туда, бл*дь, садись туда, сука, вот сюда вон, бл*дь. Молчи, бл*дь, пасть свою заткни…

— А?

— Говорю, пасть свою заткни! Так… ну я тебе щас лекцию прочитаю. Значит, японцы, перед Второй мировой войной, а именно — адмирал Ямомото, задумали расхуячить американский флот на Гавайских островах, то, что потом вошло в историю, как катастрофа в Перл Харбор. Слушай и запоминай. Командующим адмиральским флотом был адмирал Нагумо. Средний офицер на самом деле, но исполнительный… исполнительный, безусловно, профессионал. Но без фантазии, у японцев вообще людей с фантазиями было немного. Дерьмо на палочке, ничего, бл*дь, не знаешь, ничего не можешь. Чё ты вообще, бл*дь, в армии делаешь?

— Я?

— МОЛЧАТЬ! Какие самолёты были на этих авианосцах?

— А?

— Не «А». Самолёты какие были? Какой самый известный самолёт на тихоокеанском театре военных действий?

— Тигр!

— Идиот, бл*дь. СКОЛЬКО ИСТРЕБИТЕЛЕЙ, СУКА? СКОЛЬКО, бл*дь, ИСТРЕБИТЕЛЕЙ, СКОТИНА, бл*дь? 7 декабря 1941 года японский флот в составе 6 авианосцев: Акаги, Кага, Хирю, Сорю, Сёкаку и Дзуйкаку. А также двух линейных кораблей: Хией и Кирисима — появились на траверсе у острова Оаху на Гавайских островах. Первое ударное воздушное соединение насчитывало 50 истребителей «Зеро», 40 торпедоносцев и 81 пикирующий бомбардировщик. В итоге этого налёта 4 линейных корабля американского флота было потоплено. Какие корабли? КАКИЕ КОРАБЛИ? Аризона, Вест-Верджиния, Оклахома и Мэрилэнд. ЭТО ЗНАТЬ НАДО, если ты учился в шестом училище. ЭТО КЛАССИКА, БЛ*ДЬ! СКОЛЬКО ИСТРЕБИТЕЛЕЙ, СУКА? СКОЛЬКО, бл*дь, ИСТРЕБИТЕЛЕЙ, СКОТИНА, бл*дь? Сейчас наша армия ориентируется именно на этих офицеров. По крайней мере эти те немногие, кто выебли американцев в жопу. Это знать надо, дерьмо собачье. А, бл*дь, НАХ*Й! НУ ИДИ СЮДА, СУКА, бл*дь, ДЕРЬМО СОБАЧЬЕ, бл*дь, а, бл*дь. Так, ну щас чай принесут, мы с тобой продолжим, продолжим, продолжим… Ты хоть и полный идиот, но… Я думаю, что тебе эта информация будет полезна, по крайней мере в ближайший час.

review:
Ein wirklich tolles Strategie-Spiel, dass einen den Verlauf des 2. Weltkriegs nachspielen lässt. Hierbei helfen einem die verschiedenen Events, die immer wieder im Spiel ausgelöst werden und auch mit tollen Texten hinterlegt sind. Dabei muss man sich aber sicher sein, dass man nicht von jetzt auf gleich zu 100% erfolgreich sein kann. Zeit, Geduld, Schweiß und auch Niederlagen sind der Weg, um das Spiel und seine Mechaniken komplett verstehen zu können (und genau dieses Verständnis ist es, dass benötigt wird um erfolgreich zu sein). Wer sich dieser Aufgabe allerdings widmet, wird mit einem tollen Spiel-Erlebnis belohnt. 
Das Spiel mag zwar schon einige Jahre auf dem Buckel haben, allerdings kann man es noch immer wirklich gut spielen. Auch die Modder tragen hierzu bei, da sie noch immer an dem Spiel arbeiten und es einige tolle Mods gibt, um das Spiel (welches ohnehin schon recht umfangreich ist) noch umfangreicher zu gestalten.
Ich kann das Spiel wirklich nur jedem empfehlen.

author: {'steamid': '76561197965667046', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 51, 'playtime_forever': 10021, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10021, 'last_played': 1599399296}
review:
I cannot possibly write a review detailed enough to do the complexity of this game justice, so I will deliberately make it short: Arsenal of Democracy was one of my favourite global strategy games, back when Paradox still published actual games instead of DLC packs. I was really happy to see it still being maintained and updated, many years after its release. However, in my opinion, the last patch(es) made the game worse instead of improving it.

The updates to the AI (which admittedly manages its forces much more competently on the tactical level but still often acts helplessly on the grander scale) exposed a number of flaws in the game mechanics that were present before but did not show quite as glaringly in previous versions. Instead of fighting an enemy, even if it was a simulated, not always convincing effigy, I now have to fight and abuse the game's mechanics in order to win. Now Arsenal of Democracy is more work than fun for me.

In theory, it is possible to go back to older versions through Steam's beta feature. The oldest version I can select there at this moment is 1.07, which, as far as I remember, was the last one that I liked. Sadly, 1.07 doesn't seem to want to run on Windows 10. So instead of further tainting good memories by playing the later, inferior versions, I will instead just remember AoD the way it was, the way I liked it. No offense to the developers intended, I really appreciate that they're still maintaining this software. But the direction they're taking is just not for me.

review: Really want to like this game. It does, for the most part, what I like my follow war games to do, namely don't mess with the mechanics and just add more stuff for me to do and build. Extra research teams and leaders, great idea, more, diverse units to build, awesome. Then we get to the micromanaging. Re-tooling how the economies work, lousy idea. Period. I don't need more sliders to manage. No one needs more sliders to manage. Speaking of re-tooling, that concept in and of itself, while a definite real world idea, in a game on this scale, its just a time waster, since a government would just assign contracts to companies and factories that could already build the product, which is what happened in the real world. My final problem is the absolute hatred I sense from the designers for economies of scale, assembly line production, and high manpower economies and militaries. I can almost sense the anger from the developers derives from them being Axis players,  specifically German and Japanese players who watch in despair as their last manpower point is spent, while the Soviets and Americans don't break a sweat. Playing against these historical challenges is part of the fun of the HOI series, and you shouldn't arbitrarily nerf the game because you feel your favorite country starts with a bad hand dealt to it. So, yeah, play it if you want to see how HOI 3 could be upgraded, but it will be ultimately unsatisfying to jungle the extra workload.

review:
Despite some flaws, Arsenal of Democracy represents the best, most balanced, and dynamic WW2-Early Cold war simulation in the Hearts of Iron series. While I give this game a thumbs up, I think there are still some significant flaws which can make the experience a bit frustrating:

1. Naval invasion AI. Like all HoI games, the AI has never been very good at naval invasions, which cripples the allies, D-Day, if it happens, will only happen when the Germans are so weakened by the soviets, that the reds will have taken mainland europe anyway. I've never seen a situation where the allied AI manages to create a real second front to take pressure off the soviets.
2. Germans steamroll soviets more often than not. In my experience, 75% of the time the Germans completely destroy the Soviets by 1943, sometimes as early as 1 year after the eastern war starts. German tanks can be in central asia by late 1941. (Important note: I figured out this issue has a LOT to do with the speed you run the game at, while I have zero understanding of why, playing at normal speed when WW2 starts even though as the Americans or whatever you are sitting there until 1941-2 gets a more balanced outcome.)
3. AI doesn't seem to suffer from the same supply problems as the player. Keeping a large number of troops on a hostile front without a solid supply line will cripple your armies. Despite this, the AI seems to have no problem stacking troops in these same provinces. A player italy will have problems even keeping enough troops supplied to hold north africa, while AI italy seems to be able to take over the entire continent without breaking a sweat.
Nukes cause too much dissent. If the soviets manage to nuke the US twice, the country will pretty much collapse into anarchy. Same goes for the soviets, the nukes are punishing enough when they take out massive portions of an industrial base, 40% dissent seems like too much.

Despite these problems, if you get a good game going by praying to the RNG AI gods, it's an extremely technical simulation of this time period, and worth trying out if that idea interests you.

review:
10 years on and it is still the best WWII strategy game of its type out there. In some ways this game has got better with age as PC's being 10 years more powerful the game runs well to the later game stages, and lags much less these days. It is true the the AI is limited, but the attempt to stick to historical events is admirable. AoD right balance of strategy, challenge and enjoyment. There are also some well publicised in game cheats which mean you can in effect change history or create a stronger opponent, should you want to.

I have tried the games which have come since AoD, but they just don't compare and often try too hard to compete. AOD remains the standard barer for this type of game. 5 Stars.

author: {'steamid': '76561198015034934', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 28307, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4409, 'last_played': 1642365130}
review:
This is a game that I really wanted to like, but alas, no.  There are two big elements to it.  First is the opaque user interface.  I've been playing the American player, and the first thing I noticed was that there was no obvious way to rebase aircraft to remote airfields.  Right click on an aerial unit and choose rebase, and the only bases that show are ones in the adjacent province that's that, and there is no way to load aircraft onto transports(but that was done all the time for fighters in real life.   It was only after hunting down the documentation that I figured out (after trolling the interwebs) that I had to right click on a province with an airbase.   That's kind of important for the American player because all the fighting takes place away from the US, and the interface was absolutely non-intuitive .

I also found that merging naval units with transports was a royal PITA.  Sometimes it works, sometimes it doesn't.    Why? Dunno.  I looked online for the mechanics of merging units, and this is really something I shouldn't have to troll the internet to guess at.  Same thing with amphibious invasions.   I also noticed that many of the ships have range #s on them too.  Fine and dandy, but both the US Navy and the Japanese both had underway replenishment in place before WWII, and I saw no way to replicate that in-game.  That must be why in the three iterations I've played, the Japanese never bomb pearl harbor--their ships don't have the legs, and there is no way to refuel.

Another issue--where is the reconnaissance mission?  One of the biggest aspects of a game is the need to locate the enemy.  However, there is no mission available to actually allocate PBYs or B17s to fly reconnaissance and only reconnaissance--and that is a BFD.  The PBY's primary mission was to find the enemy and report back.   BTW, for some strange play balance reason, the game makes the range for these aircraft comically short.  The B17 combat radius is 400km in the game and historically it was triple that.

Another beef I have with the game is the hyper-micromanagement.  I come from Empire Total War, so I get the idea of developing an economic base, researching units etc.  However, I think the mechanic for HOI would  have a better feel if it was turn-based rather than the faster than real-time that the game uses.  It feels a little too hectic and I definitely get the feeling I'm drowning in minutiae, and not engaging in the kind of grand strategic thinking that would be part and parcel of a Churchill or Roosevelt.  Also, why should I as the player dictate who wins the election?  Isn't that the kind of thing that should only be left to chance?

Like I said earlier, I really wanted to like this game.  But there are just too many things that distract from gameplay for me to enjoy it.

review:
My original review was positive, and you can see it below, but after playing it with the latest patch, the historical event outcome on I have to say I don't recommend it. HoI2/AoD were always supposed to be more about historical accuracy than other Paradox games BUT something happen in the last couple of patches (now playing patch 11) since the German AI always gives all of Slovakia to Hungary and both Hungary, Romania and Bulgaria join the Axis before WW2 even starts, what are you doing?! I put the historical event outcomes ON, fix the game, lol.

My former review:
Overall worth it if you have the time to invest in it, I think it does a better job at representing the military, geopolitical and geoeconomical situation of the world during the late 1930s and early 1940s than other games I played, be it grand strategy games or wargames. The graphics may look outdated but work just fine, you can customize your divisions with attachments, and it's also fun as a game, although you should give it time, it's a real gem. Minuses: I don't like the aircraft or fleet battles, but that's an issue that Paradox struggles with even in Hearts of Iron 4 their newest WW2 strategy game. PS Compared to the standard HoI2 it offers lots and lots of improvements, definitely worth the buy, don't listen to people that say it's just a mod, it's not, it improves the game a lot compared to the original.

review:
I played the first hoi2 more than 10 years ago. I have spent several thousands of hours enjoying different hoi2 versions, mostly against AI, but  I cant recommend it as it is now, unless you already are player of some other variant, love it, and know how to use cheats, create mods and events in order to get a challenging campaign.

First this game was created by people who understood and/or created the game mecanhics. So the war played out mostly according to history and pretty much every nation on earth was a nice play and a possible path to become a major power. At some point the creators most probably left and moved on to other projects, but did however leave some dedicated people with the task of fixing bugs and to do further developing. This was a mixed blessing, as whoever have been assigned thoughout the years they have lacked the full understanding of the game. Some things improved, but at a cost that made the game unhistorical, imbalanced and pretty broken. As it is now, every scenario execpt the 1936 and 1945 Cold war clash will create an overpowered Soviet Union. However The 1936 scenario on the opposite creates a Germany that destroys Soviet in 1941, unless its army runs out oil first. (Current German AI more or less only buils army units that are motorised. Anybody else cringe at this totally unrealistic behavoir?)

The 1945 starts with a nuke attack on Moscow that totally cripples Soviet Union and leaves its units unsupplied and starving. Meanwhile Allied Airforce zero production capacity and supply for all Soviet sattelites. I.e quickest possible total defeat for SU. No other outcome is even possible for the best player against stupid AI. (To play this scenario you must first start as US and abort the nuke attack and restart as Soviet or continue as Allied without using nukes. I would love to hear somebody prove me wrong on this one.)

Nowadays minor nations are impossible to play without cheats. This because one of the later major changes was to radically increase production of AI-controlled nations while providing them with free research, quickly making your minor nation the weakest econmy on earth or without armed forces.

It is still possible to have alittle bit of fun by playing the AI in 36 as SU (or as Nat. China going for taking out all the 3 fractions). The 38 39 and 41 scenarios can also be a short while of fun as Germany (or Italy), before you have chrushed everybody else in 2 years or so, but there are a very few other options left to get a good game going (Eg France starting 39 defeating Germany in 1940 and than moving on to take on SU and Japan). Otherwise you got the creativity and know-how what to modify, balance and correct yourself in order to make it fly.

One of the game biggest basic flaws is the supply system that doesnt reflect the impossible logistic feat in moving large armies over great distances in the wilderness. This makes world conquest way too quick, cheap and easy.

All this said about the flaws of game - and much more could have been adressed - I would also in all fairness like add that if this game comes at a low price, you will get still get good value for your money if you never played a hoi2 game and enjoy ww2 grand strategy.

review: The basic campaign game is just fine as a WW2 simulator. I think the best fun is changing a saved game by changing governments, research levels, TC levels etc and then playing as a single country (either Russia, USA, Britain, Japan and Germany mainly) and trying to actually conquer every single province in the world before 1966 with no allies and no trade. This is still quite a struggle and lots of fun, and a lot harder than you would think. If you play Russia in 1936 with hyper tech you still need to get over the Atlantic into Canada/US before the US develop the bomb, the same with Germany. Japan taking on Russia, China and India as well as the US all at once is a challenge as well. A evil USA conquering the British empire and then choosing which Eurasian to take on first can be fun too (either Germany or USSR). Being an Evil Britain and expanding your empire at the expense of France and the US in the late 30s can also be fun, giving you lots of resources for a death match against Germany and then Russia. There is just so much you can do in this game, and that's why I have spent so much time playing it. It is way better than the Hearts of Iron games it springs from, and I hope it keeps developing. I'm a big fan!

review:
Arsenal of Democracy: A Hearts of Iron Game.

The name sound intriguing and is ripped off from one of FDR's speeches, but upon playing it, it just feels like a slightly updated twist to Hearts of Iron II. In fact, it's just a stand-alone expansion and doesn't really change much. But, it includes the Cold War and another scenario based of 'Fantasia', Armageddon.

Pros:
- Basically a cheaper Hearts of Iron II.
- Expansion is stand-alone.
- COLD WAR!
- ARMAGEDDON! (fantasy scenario.)

Cons:
- Outdated and unappealing.
- Weird glitches and in-game bugs.

Nonetheless, I recommend this game because it is essentially a cheaper Hearts of Iron II but with a grand and famed historical expansion, the Cold War! It also has a few smaller scenarios like the Korean War and the First Indo-Pakistan War, as well as ARMAGEDDON.

review:
Arsenal of Democracy ist nach Darkest Hour das zweitbeste Spiel der Hearts of Iron Reihe. Es ist etwas simpler als Darkest Hour und meiner Meinung nach ein guter Einstieg um später mit Darkest Hour weiterzumachen. Ich habe damals mit Arsenal of Democracy die HoI-Reihe kennengelernt und war einfach nur begeistert, darum habe ich es mir hier auf Steam noch einmal gekauft.

In Arsenal of Democracy kann man wie in jedem HoI-Titel die Geschichte des zweiten Weltkrieges nachspielen, oder seine ganz eigene Geschichte formen. Das Spiel ist in wenigen Stunden verstanden, doch erst in sehr sehr vielen Stunden gemeistert. Am Anfang darf man nicht frustriert sein, wenn ein Vorhaben nicht klappt und man zurückgedrängt oder gar zu einem Frieden gezwungen wird. Übung macht den Meister. Das richtige Balancing aus Wirtschaftskraft und militärischer Stärke ist enorm Wichtig, außerdem ein ausgeklügelter Plan, was wann und in welcher Größenordnung aufgebaut werden soll. Ebenso muss die Forschung auf seine Ziele ausgerichtet werden, eine breit gefächerte Forschung macht einem universell, leider damit aber auch nicht stark in gewissen Bereichen. Ein Beispiel: Für Spieler die sich für England entscheiden ist es klar, dass man seine Forschung auf Marine und Luftwaffe spezialisiert,..warum? Durch die Marine verhindert man, dass die Deutschen die Oberhand im Seekrieg gewinnen und mit der Luftwaffe sorgt man dafür, dass das englische Festland zu einer Festung wird, denn weder über den See- noch über den Luftweg kann das Deutsche Reich in England einfallen. Als Spieler des Deutschen Reiches macht es dagegen weniger Sinn seine Forschung auf die Marine zu konzentrieren, da man eben nicht durch ein Meer von seinen Kontrahenten getrennt ist. Hier ist die Priorität ganz klar zwischen Heer und Luftwaffe zu setzen, entweder Defensiv oder ganz und gar offensiv.

Zurück zum Review. Mir persönlich hat Arsenal of Democracy unheimlich viel Spaß gemacht, bis ich mich auf Darkest Hour sozusagen spezialisiert habe und dieses momentan auch bevorzuge. Aber eine klare Kaufempfehlung kann ich auch Arsenal of Democracy klar geben, denn damit hat für mich alles angefangen und jeder Liebhaber von großen Strategiespielen wird seinen Spaß an diesem Spiel haben. Zumindest solange man auf Echtzeit-Kämpfe, die man selber steuern kann, verzichten kann, denn diese gibt es in HoI nicht.

Das Spiel erhällt auch heutzutage noch Hotfixes und Beta-Patches, obwohl es schon 2010 veröffentlicht wurde.

review:
AoD is a mod for Hearts of Iron 2: Doomsday. And while it's 9 years old, they're still working on it, which is rather amazing.

In AoD you pick any of the provided starting dates (earliest is 1-1-1936), pick any country and you run it - sort of. You can engage in diplomacy, politics, research, espionage, trade, production and warfare. At certain historical dates events will fire for some countries which generally offer a historical and ahistorical option. For instance, as the USSR you can decline to carry out Stalin's purge of the army. This will benefit your research and military strength, but at the cost of a gigantic dissent penalty (50%) which can cripple your industry.

It's basically a "what-if" simulator. What if th left won in Spain and, say, joined the Allies? What if Barbarossa completely succeeded or failed? Or maybe what if Brazil or Turkey got involved? There's a substantial amount of skill and knowledge involved, but you can do some fun things. And of course you already know what's going to happen. As the USSR you can build a huge army and powerful fortifications and stop Hitler much earlier.

AoD does have a big problem: the interface. There's no proper overview of all your provinces with all information you might want (like resource production). Budgetting involves messing with terrible, clumsy, poorly responding sliders. Very little information is given about many things. And construction can't be reduced or paused from the province screen.

Also, smaller countries are overly punished by the research system that relies on Industrial Capacity. And it takes so much time. A single game can take dozens of hours. But yeah, the interface is what really killed the game for me. So i'd recommend it, but only if you can live with quite a bit of tedium.

author: {'steamid': '76561198101864665', 'num_games_owned': 2556, 'num_reviews': 159, 'playtime_forever': 4733, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4409, 'last_played': 1569340945}
review:
虽然现在还没玩四代，但是钢铁雄心系列的确实有一个越来越细化的趋势。
而二代的两个扩展版，黑暗时刻和民主兵工厂提供了后续作品中两个十分重要的设定：前者是决议、动员系统，后者则是堆叠惩罚、更加复杂的补给系统（这个系统也坑苦了末日剧本总是吃核弹的苏修，233）等。
和黑暗时刻丰富剧本内容和提供新剧本不同，民主兵工厂则是对二代的系统做出了较大更改，而剧本设定基本跟P社的2代一样。
在民主兵工厂中，基佬逻辑（手动滑稽）这个制作组丰富了工业的设定，比如，虽然面粉厂造航母依旧无法改变，但是工业能力（IC）的影响因素更加多样化；资金分配和贸易也被单独做了出来，等等。在政治上，国策条可以自由拉动，但是作为平衡，不到时间强行拉政策条会吃不满（没这一点就跟输了freedom秘籍没什么区别了）；更重要的是引入了国家理念这个BUFF系统，不同国家的不同理念丰富了游戏体验，也为mod的创作提供了新的可能。而在游戏的核心——军事上，本游戏相较于原版做出的变动可以说时相当之大的：以陆战为例，比如游戏的堆叠惩罚系统克制无脑盖楼平推，更加强调多路协同作战（但是默认设置1个师就会有堆叠也太反人类了，每次玩我都会在misc.txt里面调一下）；命令部队做出行动也要等待一定的时间，不再像2代原版那样指哪打哪，这种设定也真实了不少（三代也继变向继承了这个设定）；挂炮的师可以进行支援炮击，提高进攻的效率等等。空战和海战也有一定的变化，本陆军马路就不再陈述了。
另外，和黑暗时刻一样，AOD系列也有不少成熟的MOD，国内的话，也有不少制作精良的mod，如果啤酒馆，MIH（历史的瞬间）等等。
=====================================================
总结：
在steam上能买到的钢铁雄心系列有234三部，而这三部的画风完全不同，每一部都可以给你带来不同的体验
如果想体验2代的话，P社的原版（Heart of Iron 2 Complete可以作为收藏），玩的话还是推荐AOD和DH（黑暗时刻）
一些游戏的可玩性，是不会因时间的推进和画面的落后而降低的
=====================================================
再说说这个制作组的一些事吧，几年前，这个组和P社合作要出一款冷战背景的大战略游戏，内容包括了政治经济和军事，以钢三为平台，可惜是饼画的太大，最后还是不了了之，只有一个未完成的版本流传到网上，可惜，可惜·····
不过冷战的世界和二战的世界比起来的确复杂了不少，想要模拟冷战的世界，难度可想而知·····

So in any case. .. this is it!

review:
The best Hearts of Iron game to this date in my opinion. 

Pros
+ Good model for large war like WW2 was
+ Simplistic enough for relaxing "heavy" strategy game experience (it's deep enough)
+ You can make alternative history without frustrating micro managering
+ You can play with all countries on WW2 era
+ Manpower system is better in this game than it's counter parts (HOI2, Darkest Hour, HOI3)
+ You can conquer whole world (You can't do that in HOI4 which focus for single wars)

Cons
- Industrial Capacity system favor larger countries
- AI navy is still broken and doesn't need harbors same way like player needs (you can't make buffer zones in naval fights by conquering all harbors at certain areas)

review:
Compre este juego hace casi 1 año junto con otros juegos de Paradox, Lamentablemente no lo pude jugar desde el minuto 1 por que tengo una placa AMD, en ves de devolverlo, Decidi tener paciencia por que sabia que algun dia, iban a arreglarlo, Hoy, casi 1 año despues pude jugarlo por primera ves (ayer lo repararon). author: {'steamid': '76561198118095881', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 7786, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6760, 'last_played': 1500592523}
review:
Love this version of the game and highly recommend it to anyone into strategic war games.

Though i continue to be plagued by the Americans when ever i play as the Germans... 

Latest Game:
Year 1943 January - Germany controls Europe (only Switzerland, Sweden, Italy, England/Ireland and Finland not occupied), control north Africa along with Italy. Pushed the Soviets back passed Moscow and only getting sparse resistance from this at this point - also control most of the middle east. The US finally enters the war on the side of the allies (something i had been expecting since 1941).

Year 1943 April - United States performs Torch Landings in North Africa (Casablanca), brush away the 3 divisions of garrison infantry (1941 tech level) - with 6 mixed divisions of their own. I move my quick response army group - comprised of elite mechanized and armored divisions, 12 of them in total under Rommel (level 6 general) to hit them - expecting to crush them (as to date my groups like that have crushed anything they have ran into) - the 6 american units blast the snot ouf of my quick response unit. Im a little shocked, but things happen in war - luckly i had two slower moving army groups near the area and moved them to intercept the american force will withdrawing my battered 12 divisions...  hit the americans with a further 24 divisions comprised of mix forces, artillery. AT, assault guns, ect..ect.. still going up against 6 divisions... get my arse handed to me again. Double check my intel on USA - agents tell me im more advanced than them in tech in all areas of ground combat - so totally confused at the loses.

Year 1943 July - American forces have pushed me back to italian held north africa. Ive halted my advance into russia and agree to peace treaty with them and start moving units from the eastern front back to the western front. British try landing near Gibraltar, but i crush it with garrison forces. But for what ever anything i throw at the americans bounces off. Had a total of 40 divisions in north africa get pushed back... even after i diverted 90% of my luftwaffe to strike them (from what i could tell i had complete air superiority).

Year 1943 December (Present) - US forces control North africa all the way to the suez. Repeat review of intel tells me im still more advanced than the americans in every category of ground technology. Even with fortress in tubruk and such, the US army just rolls over me repeatedly. I have nearly 70 divisions sitting across the Suez, most have been sitting there for weeks - so fully supplied and rested. But some how i suspect the US is just gonna roll over me again. (and usually they hit me with at most 6-10 divisions per engagement). British try repeatedly to attack in norway and france, and get squashed every time... then the US lands in Spain and steam rolls the defenses i have there too...again swatting away 12 panzer divisions like they were nothing.

Have no idea why i cant beat the US forces. Though its been fun actually getting pushed across Africa, though i was hoping for successful counter attacks a few times - especially when i starrted throwing my very experience russian front unit at them... never been handed my arse so badly before.

review: Der beste Teil aus dem "Hearts of Iron Universum". Im groben Abriss: Die Spielmechanik ist, im Vergleich zu den Vorgänger-Spielen, deutlich strukturierter und tiefgründiger. Grafisch zeigt sich das Spiel zweckdienlich, wobei es kostenfreie Grafik-Modifikationen (Skins, Fotos, etc.) im Internet zu finden gibt. Anders als die Nachfolger (HoI III etc.) kommt das Produkt ohne Extrakosten (DLC's), ganz in Tradition zu HoI I und II, aus. author: {'steamid': '76561198005304313', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 100393, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 77945, 'last_played': 1700498863}
review:
Historisch soweit möglich korrekt und politisch neutral bietet HoI2 (AoD) ein in jeder Partie aufs Neue spannendes Weltkriegsszenario. Das Spiel benötigt eine kurze Einarbeitung, erschlägt neue Spieler aber nirgends mit unmengen Micro-Management-Schiebereglern.

Entgegen der Shop-Beschreibung ist das Spiel auch auf Deutsch spielbar. In den Spieleigenschaften stehen zusätzlich Spanisch, Französisch, Italienisch, Portugiesisch und Polnisch zur Wahl.

Es werden reale Orte und Personen verwendet. So kan ein Stück Geschichte nachgespielt und gleichzeitig etwas gelernt werden. Obwohl vermutlich nicht mit "Gamification" im Hinterkopf programmiert, erhält man durch das Spiel ganz nebenbei gute Kenntnisse von Geographie und Zeitgeschichte.

Der Spielfluss wird durch echte historische Ereignisse bestimmt, denen der Spieler allerdings nicht zwingend folgen muss. Als Deutschland lieber nicht auf der Übergabe Danzigs beharren und den Kriegsausbruch herauszögern? Als USA 1936 lieber Landon statt Roosevelt zum Präsidenten wählen?  Mit Mexiko Nordamerika angreifen? Wie sich die Geschichte bei solchen Abweichungen entwickelt, bestimmen der Spieler und im Hintergrund ein kleiner Zufallsgenerator.

Wer gerne wissen möchte, wie die KI auf die eigene Strategie reagiert, kann jederzeit einen bestehenden Spielstand aus der Perspektive eines anderen Landes ganz normal weiterspielen - zur Wahl stehen stets ALLE im Spielstand bestehenden Länder der HoI2-Erde.

Die Community des Spiels ist nach all den Jahren weiterhin aktiv und erstellt Patches, die seit Kurzem auch von Steam automatisch ausgeliefert werden. Deren Entwicklung kann man in den einschlägigen Foren selbst beeinflussen und kommentieren. Seit Version 1.11 wurde das Spiel grundlegend modernisiert und ist fit für moderne Hardware und Betriebssystemversionen.

Es existieren zahlreiche Mods und das Spiel ist generell sehr gut anpassbar - im Installationsverzeichnis befinden sich alle nötigen Dateien in einem von jedem Texteditor verwertbaren Format. So können neue Ereignisse, neue Forschungen, neue politische und militärische Führer etc. eingefügt oder bestehende verändert werden. Im Grunde kann man jeden Aspekt des Spiels anpassen. Mit wenigen Klicks ist eine eigene Kampagne erstellt, in der beispielsweise Honduras mit modernster Technologie aber nur wenigen Truppen nach der Weltherrschaft strebt.

Es braucht weder HD-Texturen noch 3D um ein gutes Strategiespiel zu machen. Mir bereitet HoI2 AoD dank der kleinen, sinnvollen Abweichungen vom "normalen" HoI2 von allen bisherigen Spielen der Reihe - inkl. der Nachfolger - am meisten Spaß.

review:
Что ж, приступим.
Arsenal of Democtacy - великолепная стратегия, но при этом рассчитаная на хардкорных игроков.
Начал играть в нее я еще на пиратке, однако во время скидок на серию "Hearts of Iron" решился поддержать монеткой разработчиков и купил пак второй части игры.
Скажу честно, игра очень легка для вхождения, интуитивно управляемая, но при этом невероятно сложна.
Но, обо всем по порядку.
Графика в игре звезд не хватает, хотя этим отличаются первые три части серии. Но, тут хотя бы установлены спрайты по-умночалу, что приятнее (по-крайней мере мне) чем символьные обозначения. О карте особо сказать нечего, так как вы можете открыть любой атлас и увидите похожую картину.
Звук так же не особо хорош. Фоновая музыка быстро приедается, звуки опопещений тоже. Но, с другой стороны звук не особо важен в подоных играх.
Геймплей - это именно то, на чем вытягивается вся игра. Сам по-себе он не особенно уникален: Изучаем, Строим, Изучаем, Улучшаем и по новой. Однако, созавать армии, подбирать им поддержку, строить планы - по-настоящему интересно. Видов юнитов много, от банальной пехоты, заканчивая ядерным оружием. Хотя, разочаровывает то, что некоторые юниты возвери в ранг поддержки, например тяжелые танки. Но, это не отменяет того, что геймплей в игре захватывающий. исследование, производство, политика, разведка.  Можно придумать 1000 и 1 способ захватить весь мир, однако...
Даже на минимальной сложности ИИ способен нагнуть игроков, при этом не только новичков. Противник умело пользуется флотом и авиацией, войсками спец назначения. Казалось бы, вот ты вырезал весю армию врага и победоносно идешь к столице, но...У врага внезапно обраруживаются еще OVER90 территорий 2)Вам в тыл высаживаются N-количество ВДВ/МП и победоносным шагом идут прямо к столице. И все, нет такой страны как Сиам.
Так же, по неясным причинам, изучение технологий у ИИ идет быстрее, чем у игрока.
А еще игра явно не слышала про историческую достоверность...
Армия Японии гордо приближалась к Берлину, намереваясь его захватить, но Гитлер сбежал в Африку, вытесняя тамошних Африканцев и Китайцев...Китай с обиды уничтожает второй, более маленький Китай, ввязав в войну СССР, столица которого находится в Новосибирске...
Впрочем, именно этот необуздаемый ИИ и явзяется причиной, по которой охото играть.
Я рекомендую эту игру любителям сложных стратегий, так как ИИ не знает посчады, а его хитрость и нелогичность выведет из себя любого.

review:
接触这类游戏六七年了，这也算是我玩的最久的一款游戏了吧，任何我长期使用的pc设备都安着这个游戏(其实就四部)。记得高一还是初三的时候刚开始接触这游戏上手花了几乎半月，到后面才基本明白各种机制的运作方式，比起复杂的三代还是二代最简单粗暴，尤其用美国或者日本对垒太平洋，简直有趣到极限。
比起其他的战略模拟游戏，hoi的特点是充分贯彻了近代化工业战争的基本要素，不仅是装备与兵力，后勤，制空，组织度等因素也从各个方面决定着战斗的走向，同时国家工业发展与政治情况也对作战有反作用。
总之这游戏无论是做简单政治模拟还是简单战役模拟都是蛮不错的。就是ai智商太捉鸡这点有点让人崩溃

review:
回顾接触的第一款HOI，就是AOD，简直是一开始就被带歪了，毕竟这是个HOI2的MOD的独立版。
当年一度沉迷，现在再玩，还是感觉得到经典的魔力。
以前的MOD完成度不知比现在的MOD高到哪里去了，不但军事方面大改HOI2原版，首创了堆叠惩罚，炮击支援一系列机制，还把政治外交改得不错。以前我不懂Libertarian Individualism是什么，不懂Liberal是什么，不懂很多政治哲学概念，只当AOD里这些是可以换来换去的BUFF，现在懂了才发现这些设定真是耐人寻味。可惜P社自己的HOI4现在把政治基本简化掉了，军事方面倒是从3开始开始懂得搞战场宽度和堆叠惩罚了，算是和AOD学了一手。
科研方面其实比HOI4更真实，毕竟有科研经费这个机制，没经费可研究不动，哪像HOI4，科研人员全部喝西北风搞研究。
另外当年没有舰娘，不然那时候这游戏就可以趁着能大建各种船在提督里刷一波知名度了（大雾
但是HOI系列的通病还是那样，国家和计划思想过重，看不见市场和私人投资的影子，简单的“大炮还是黄油”式的IC分配并不能表现经济真正的样貌，本质还是暴兵后打打打战战战的游戏。
随便碎碎念两句，不说太多，总之，这游戏，值得一玩。

P.S. Win10能正常运行真是太好了。
P.S.2 Win10到安装目录的settings.cfg里，把0 #WINDOWED MODE改成1 #WINDOWED MODE，1024 #Width 768 #Height改成任意想要的分辨率，然后右键aodgame.exe，在属性里选兼容性，设置简化的颜色模式成16位色，就能窗口化运行了。

author: {'steamid': '76561198112810429', 'num_games_owned': 2591, 'num_reviews': 578, 'playtime_forever': 5077, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3627, 'last_played': 1454849549}
review:
Very thorough remake of Hearts of Iron 2 - it is wider and deeper than original game, which itself is very wide and deep in terms of every fan of turn-based global strategies.
It was released not as mod but as a separate game due to significant amount of gameplay changes above the original HOI2 game. And it is still under development! Get me right - Arsenal of Democracy is a finished product, yet there are always room for some improvements and additional campaigns and stuff. And yeah, community is friendly, and welcome for any newcomers, but...

But I won't recommend you to start with Paradox games from this title. There are way too many options, details, charts and graphs to sink in... So you'll get by better starting from Europa Universalis 3 or even Victoria 2, than with Arsenal of Democracy.
So I do recommend the game - but only for prepared ones, who grown up above the basic things Civilization taught us, and ready to spend dozens or even hundreds of hours on single separate scenario, making his own history. There are so many scenarios and mods to prove yourself on... And if you'll be not getting enough, you can always make some of your own.

Finally, I must inform you that there are a major bug still troubling some players - a flickering screen problem. For some people the game works straight out of box, some have to go to Paradox forums and download patches (Steam is releasing 1.04 version now, and current patch on Paradox is 1.09 or maybe 1.10 already). And for some systems flickering goes on forever, like how it goes with my laptop. So I warn you! There is a possibility that this game will be unplayable, no matter how great it is...

My mark is 8/10. I'd like to give the game more, but flickering bug is still a big issue, even after 5+ years after game release.

author: {'steamid': '76561198029561684', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 239, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 239, 'last_played': 1446316556}
review:
There is cleary a lot of content here, and it seems to be a labor of love. That said, there are some issues here that make it difficult for me to recommend. Most of these issues boil down to learning curve and how much time you're willing to commit to figuring the game out. There are a few in-game tutoials, and the manual is easy enough to find on-line, but it's still a very difficult game to get your arms around. The tutorials are enough to get you started, but probably cover about 1% of the in game scenarios. 

The manual gives a broad overview, but didn't shed any light on issues that I had with playability. I found units behaving contrary to orders that I was giving frequently. I had no doubt that the behavior was rational given the rules of the game, but became frustrated trying to figure it out without any feedback from the game. This was a shame, because the level of effort put into historical accuracy is impressive, as is the amount of control the designers are trying to offer. 

I really wanted to like this game, but after three hours of wrestling with the interface, I decided to try something else. Maybe I gave up too soon, but with the number of available games on Steam at this price point, it seemed like I was needlessly banging my head against the wall instead of enjoying myself.

author: {'steamid': '76561197963878724', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 3919, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 18, 'last_played': 1660577933}
review:
This game was great to begin with, but it has recently undergone some major updates in the form of version 1.09. Sadly the latest patch is not available on Steam, but it can be downloaded from Paradox forums, where you can register your game and get access to the patches https://forum.paradoxplaza.com/forum/index.php?forums/arsenal-of-democracy.462/

There is even a 1.10 patch in early alpha stage, the patch will attempt to adress the ancient bugs and problems with the game engine.

Graphics arent anything wonderfull, but this is about grand strategy, not fancy fireworks.

Game in itself is straight up Hearts of Iron, if your a Paradox fan, then you will love AoD aswell. Multitude of variation in strategy, tactics, diplomacy, large techtree, plenty of unit types and so much little details to think of that after years of playing, you still learn new things every now and then. It has the best replayability value that I have ever seen in a strategy game. If you have not played Paradox games before, then you are up for a long and hard path of learning the game, but it is very much worth it.

The AI is not terribly challenging once you master the game, the difficulty setting just grants it more bonuses rather than intelligence, but luckily there are alot of mods that improve the AI and gameplay generally, such as my own mod which can be downloaded here:
https://forum.paradoxplaza.com/forum/index.php?threads/improved-1936.673291/

Best way to enjoy this game however is in multiplayer, there are various forums where you can sign up and try to find an MP game to join, Paradox forum is a good place to start. You need GameRanger to get access to online game as the game itself has no lobby function anymore.

In multiplayer the game springs to life, as you can co-op as Axis or Allies, or a desperate struggle as Poland/Czechoslovakia with your friend, the choices are limitless. But best games are the ones where all the major powers are controlled by a human player, that is where things get real. The games progress relatively slowly due to amount of players, but in also forces you to cooperate with your allies and form plans and strategies which can be equally fun as playing the game itself.

All in all, this is my favourite WW2 Grand strategy game and has been since its release. No other game has come even close, so I can recommend it with all my heart.

author: {'steamid': '76561198008163098', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 69, 'playtime_forever': 3337, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 682, 'last_played': 1481619296}
review:
If you like to play a refined, polished Version of HOI 2 (including the two addons) with all the little gameplay additions you always felt missing in the original, go for Arsenal of Democracy.

Here an (incomplete) list of additions and tweaks I found to be a major improvement over the vanilla version:

- Extended Scenario time up to the 60s.
- Option to enable Democracies to declare war (I'm not a fan of the original DOW mechanic)
- Units win a battle, then move to occupy the province (no insta occupation)
- Enhanced Tech Trees
- Diplomacy Option to forbid allies to send expeditionary forces
- Ship upgrades!
- Improved intelligence system
- Improved Transport/Trade/Transport Capacity parameters
- Key Industries like synthetic oil plants in certain provinces!
- rebuilding provinces is part of the economy now: Strategic bombardements really hurt.
- Overall improved eceonomic system with additional sliders: i.e. military and civilian spendings can be adjusted
- additional sandbox and historical scenarios

I own HOI3 as well and for me Arsenal of Democracy is the far better game. While HOI3 is slow, overcomplicated and cuts back on the  player's influence, AoD gives you all the freedeom and possibilities you want to create the crazy "What if" scenarios you always wanted to play out.

Highly recommended!

review:
9 of 10

The game is very in-depth with managing your country without sacrificing the military part of the game. The only thing that keeps it from a full 10 is that there is no editor for AoD like the first Hearts of Iron and the worst part is that the description is a lie. There is NO editor with the game nor is there a seperate editor tool, the only way to edit is the old fashioned way, screwing around with save game files using wordpad and/or notepad.

Even without a real editor however you can still accomplish a great deal with wordpad editing with hoi 1 and 2, something hoi 3 lacks is the freedom to edit with wordpad (most hoi 3 files, mainly the save games and scenario files, are   in a file format not compatable with wordpad.)

Overall it is better than the successor, hoi 3 in every way except map graphics, particularly because the regions in hoi 3 on the US dont take into account the accurate shape of the states where in all hoi games precedding, the states are accurately shaped by region and province shape.

They should remove from the list of features that (or at least rephrase it to point out that the files are wordpad editable instead of insinuating a non-existant editor) the hints of an editor that doesn't exist before someone decides to bash them with false advertisement OR solve the problem altogether by making an editor for AoD much like the first Hearts of Iron Scenario Editor which had an interactive map in which to set province ownership and the like.

If an editor exists for AoD then I would appreciate anyone messaging me or leaving a comment on my profile if the former is not possible with information on where to get it.

Aside from the lies about an editor however the game is great and is both historical and ahistorical as the AIs don't always make the same choices every game, meaning a lot of "what-if" scenarios can happen (Like the possibility of Germany mobilizing late, Stalin deciding not to purge his officers or Japan not attacking Pearl Harbor, though the major historical events the AI usually chooses the historical outcome often.)

So all in all, great game, 9 out of 10, if they put in a user-friendly editor to make the lies not lies, then it would be a 10, until they decide to do that however, it remains an imperfect yet high 9/10.

I highly reccomend this game with or without an editor due to the large array of choices you have at your disposal when managing your country (such as taking steps to turn america into a dictatorship, or being a non-insane hitler who focuses on the USSR instead of world domination or even playing as the Soviets and being the reason for WW2 instead of germany or even the very difficult yet still possible scenario where France doesn't become a cheese eating surrender monkey and actually fights the second world war.)

author: {'steamid': '76561198097450944', 'num_games_owned': 230, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 13147, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4392, 'last_played': 1708061630}
review:
Como apreciador do jogos de estratégia , Eu recomendo esse jogo!

No começo achei que era um jogo fraco, mas depois vi que era um jogo que tem grande potencial, pois as imagens que apresentam na página da loja dele não são muito atraentes , mais depois de jogar vi que era excelente , e muito personalizavel de um certo ponto de vista , não falo de fazer novos países ou algo do tipo , digo sobre fazer alianças , negociações , conquistar territorios , pesquisar unidades , treinamento , economia e produção.

Com o passar dos anos o jogo reproduz acontecimentos , por exemplo , Tratados que aconteceram na história , Invasões históricas e grandes batalhas da Segunda Guerra , O destino do mundo estará em suas mãos se souber comandar seus homens a vitória.

Com uma variedade razoavel de países para comandar , sendo que o jogo se extende não só na Segunda guerra , mais sim em várias outras guerras , Como a Guerra da coréia , etc , É dependendo do pais ele mostra unidades que só aquele pais tinha na época , exemplo , quando se mostra uma divisão aérea , não mostra só caças e pronto , mostram qual caça é e todas as informações , exemplo , BF-109D que é usado em 1936 no modo campanha pela Alemanha.

O jogo se passa de 1936 a 1964 , é um periodo razoavel para dominação do mundo , com muitos paises para invadir e fazer alianças o tempo não ajuda , assim como o clima , economia e politica , que influencia muito na guerra , podendo causas crises , etc.

Um dos poucos jogos que ainda funciona em Multiplayer , Via hamachi ou Gameranger (Jogo pelo Gameranger) e é muito mais divertido jogar com os amigos do que jogar sozinho com bots que não te ajudam e não pensam do seu jeito , só querem invadir e conquistar e pronto , para eles é assim , não existe muita estratégia , mas voltando ao multiplayer é otimo , recomendo que se for jogar multiplayer usem a campanha de 1938 (a que da pra escolher mais países).

review:
I come at this as one who originally played HoI3 followed by Darkest Hour. AoD focuses very much on domestic and economic issues (repairing provinces, civic investment as a means to alleviating dissent as opposed to simply cranking out consumer goods). It's really sliders galore. The implimentation of over-arching, nation-wide policies is also nice.
What this game could use, however, is a bit more UI polish. To use the technology tree as an example -- colors seem stark and non-period while useability refinements such as historical years within each tech's respective title should have been implimented. The AI also makes questionable ahistoric decisions, leaving history-minded players stuck. If you're open-minded and wanting unpredictablity though, that might be right up your alley.

All that being said, I recommend this to players wanting diplomatic and policy-heavy gameplay without losing military action.

author: {'steamid': '76561197964153663', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 246, 'playtime_forever': 8422, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6546, 'last_played': 1414087879}
review:
Arsenal of Democracy: A Hearts of Iron Game. The hint is in the title, a Hearts of Iron game. This is not really a game however, Arsenal of Democracy is a free mod available to all Hearts of Iron 2 players and this retail version only has a few minor advantages over the free version.

If you want to know whether this game is for you then you should not be reading this review, rather you should find a review for the regular Hearts of Iron 2, everything said in there is true for this game. With one notable exception however, none of the Hearts of Iron 2 mods will work for this.

It is a strange sense, to pay money for the retail version of a mod only to be denied access to, what is otherwise one of the strongest modding scenes around. Arsenal of Democracy does have some mods available made specifically for this game but they are few and far between and none have the scope or polished quality that is readily available for Hearts of Iron 2.

All in all, do not buy this, simply don't. If you are such a big fan of the genre that you must play every incarnation out there then save yourself some money, go get Hearts of Iron 2 instead and download the Arsenal of Democracy mod free of charge, you won't be missing out on much and should you want a slightly different total conversion of the World War 2 Grand Strategy experience, you simply download another mod.
